stream_context.summary: Kaze uses most of the stream to plan the Yoshi’s Island overworld and enumerate new “single-mechanic” side levels while giving a progress report on his newly-rewritten sound engine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has spent the last 4-5 days ripping out Mario 64’s original sound engine and replacing it; code size dropped ~5 KB, memory allocations were reduced, and overall performance is “huge[ly]” improved.
development_findings.quote: I’m trying to fix Mario 64 sound engine. It sucks. I’ve probably spent the last four or five days non-stop on it … I have reduced the code size by probably like five kilobytes.

development_findings.summary: Overworld layout is largely complete; remaining tasks include the Bowser drill area, a Yoshi village zone, and general detailing/UV-mapping.
development_findings.quote: The world is done layout-wise, yes … except for maybe this part here.

development_findings.summary: Bowser’s drill will bore toward the island’s centre but be halted by a magical barrier that unlocks after collecting enough stars; Kaze is still figuring out how to telegraph the drill/barrier visually.
development_findings.quote: How do we make sure the player knows it's a drill, but also the barrier keeps them out? That's a good question.

development_findings.summary: Empty spaces will be filled with themed structures: a Yoshi playground (swings, seesaw shortcut), a fruit-juice bar, hammocks, tree houses, a flower farm, wool warehouse, small boats and other ‘village’ props.
Kaze formalised a design rule for new side levels: reuse existing mechanics, require no new code, and be buildable in a day.
development_findings.quote: At this point I don’t want to add side levels that add that much work to the project. If anything I want the side levels … to be based on a mechanic we already have.

development_findings.summary: Planned side levels now include: a timed manta-ray coin run, a minecart dash, a cloud-cap sky fortress, a Shy-Guy hide-and-seek arena, an egg/ball-rolling pinball course inside a Yoshi arcade, a planetary-gravity red-coin planet, a shell-diving race versus a shark, and a timed ‘pick-your-power’ canyon run.
Total planned stars rose to 189; ultimate goal remains 200, with ~41 coming from overworld secrets.
development_findings.quote: We have 189 stars planned now … if we get 11 more stars we have 200.

development_findings.summary: Large Bubba fish will ring the island to prevent players from swimming around its perimeter and bypassing content.
development_findings.quote: There’s going to be huge babas that will eat you if you go out because I don’t want to deal with having to program that.

development_findings.summary: Engine and tools will be released as open source when the hack ships so others can build on the performance gains.
development_findings.quote: Yes definitely, I do want people to use my engine to make more romhacks.

development_findings.summary: A scavenger-hunt star that spans the entire overworld is being prototyped using signpost clues and landmark hints.

NPC migration system: completing certain missions makes characters move into the overworld (e.g., Poochie appears after Course 2 and can fetch a coin; an ex-oil-rig worker sells decorations like a pinball machine for 1000 coins).

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels overworked; today involved major sound-engine work plus stream prep and sponsorship chores.
context_findings.quote: God, I had so much stuff to do today. Holy shit.

context_findings.summary: He is financially reliant on sponsor videos handled by agency LFI; invoice mistakes and sales-tax issues have him worried about actually getting paid.
context_findings.quote: Something’s fucked up, and now I don’t know whether I’m actually going to get paid or not, which would be devastating.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is unfazed by potential Nintendo takedowns, saying he would rebrand the project and use the publicity.
context_findings.quote: If it happens, it happens … I can still just turn it into my own branded game, hopefully.

context_findings.summary: Personal stance: considers Reddit/4chan time-wasters, dislikes Squid Game, and lives in Canada.
He believes most programming tasks are conquerable, joking that “all programming is easy.”
context_findings.quote: How hard is it to code for N64? Easy. All programming is easy.

biobak.summary: Actively provided design feedback in chat, suggesting timer alternatives, cautioning about new mechanics, and reminding Kaze of star overlap issues.

key_stories.title: Rewriting the Sound Engine
key_stories.summary: Kaze has gutted Mario 64’s audio system, spending nearly a week optimizing and rebuilding it for better memory use and performance.
key_stories.challenge: Vanilla Mario 64 audio was buggy, heavy, and restrictive for new music.
key_stories.process: Ripped out legacy code, rewrote allocation logic, shrank binary size by ~5 KB, and squashed longstanding bugs.
key_stories.outcome: A faster, leaner audio engine that frees RAM for the ROM-hack and simplifies future OST work.
key_stories.key_quote: Once that’s done, we’re going to have such a much stronger sound engine compared to the vanilla game.

key_stories.title: Side-Level Philosophy Pivot
key_stories.summary: To push the star count to 200 without ballooning scope, Kaze invents ‘single-mechanic’ side levels that reuse existing code.
key_stories.challenge: Need more stars but little bandwidth for fresh systems.
key_stories.process: Inventory existing mechanics (manta ray, minecart, cloud cap, etc.) and brainstorm short, self-contained challenges.
key_stories.outcome: Eight new side levels drafted, raising planned total to 189 stars.
key_stories.key_quote: If anything I want the side levels that we now add … to be based on a mechanic we already have.

key_stories.title: Bowser’s Drill Dilemma
key_stories.summary: The overworld set-piece of Bowser drilling through a magic barrier conflicts spatially with Boshi’s platform.
key_stories.challenge: Drill, barrier and Boshi currently occupy the same area and look awkward.
key_stories.process: On-stream brainstorming about resizing landmass and visual cues for the barrier.
key_stories.outcome: Decision to shrink terrain and place the drill so players can see it behind the barrier; final visuals TBD.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe Boshi should be shooting the shit somewhere else.

key_stories.title: Poochie Joins the Island
key_stories.summary: After players beat Poochie’s course mission, the dog will relocate to the overworld and perform a small coin-fetch trick.
key_stories.challenge: Wanted tangible rewards for story continuity.
key_stories.process: Designing an NPC migration system where mission completion toggles overworld spawns.
key_stories.outcome: Poochie becomes a living prop that adds life (and a coin) to the hub.
key_stories.key_quote: When you step on his head he walks to a random spot and picks up one singular coin.

key_stories.title: Sponsor Agency Anxiety
key_stories.summary: Kaze relies on agency LFI for video sponsorships but recent invoicing errors threaten payments.
key_stories.challenge: Videos cost money to make; sponsor cash flow is uncertain.
key_stories.process: Back-and-forth with agency, chasing Squarespace about unpaid invoice; checks stream mid-show for updates.
key_stories.outcome: Issue with Squarespace resolved during stream, but lingering doubts remain.
key_stories.key_quote: I was convinced it’s Squarespace’s fault … but then they also fucked up my invoice, so now I’m not sure anymore.

open_questions.topic: Technical specifics of the new sound engine
open_questions.context: Kaze claims big performance gains but gave no implementation detail.
questions: What concrete architectural changes did you make to Mario 64’s audio pipeline?
How will the new engine benefit composers like Badub?
Were there any console hardware limits you had to fight?

open_questions.topic: Visual execution of Bowser’s drill and magic barrier
open_questions.context: Unsure how to show the drill without clipping or confusing players.
questions: What final visual language will communicate the drill’s purpose and the barrier’s impassability?
Is there concept art or prototyping footage?
How will Boshi’s location be re-worked?

open_questions.topic: Scope control via single-mechanic side levels
open_questions.context: Many side levels were drafted quickly; feasibility and pacing remain untested.
questions: Which of these eight side levels are top priority?
How will you measure whether they truly take ‘one day’?
Could any be cut if schedule slips?
How will star rewards be balanced so players don’t feel overwhelmed?

open_questions.context: Multiple characters will move into the hub as stars are earned.
questions: What systems manage state changes for migrating NPCs?
How will these NPCs interact with each other and the player long-term?
Could this mechanic expand to quests or dialogue trees?

open_questions.context: Payment delays jeopardise Kaze’s video funding and possibly development time.
questions: How critical are sponsor dollars to overall project viability?
What contingency plans exist if agency partnerships fall through?
Would crowd-funding or Patreon be considered?

open_questions.topic: Nintendo legal risk and contingency branding
open_questions.context: Kaze is not worried but no concrete plan shared.

Has legal counsel been consulted?
Could an original-IP fork diverge quickly enough to retain fan interest?

open_questions.topic: Team workload and division of labour
open_questions.context: Biobak contributes graphics but timeline pressures are mentioned; Zeina and Badub not present.
questions: What is each member’s current task list and bandwidth?
How are deadlines communicated and tracked?
